annotation.TEXT: All in all, while I could rant about the needless removal of the annotation system, I don't want to end this video on a sour note. The annotations had a good run while they lasted. So, here's to their departure, and to the updated commentary style. Looking forward to hearing all of your thoughts on it once the next video is up!

If you've already beaten the game, you can use Samus' weapon on repeat playthroughs (along with a weapon from Staticreator's other game - but again, more on that later). The Samus Missile is strong enough to one shot most minor enemies, including a few that are otherwise immune to the regular buster.

Something interesting to note is that this stage has branching paths. Going the top route in the previous vertical section brings you to a different series of rooms. Ultimately though, it ends up being a bit pointless, seeing as it just loops back around to the vertical room. I guess it's supposed to be simulating Metroid's maze-like design, but I think there's better ways to pull that off.

Even after all these years, I honestly still haven't found a solid strategy for fighting Samus in this game. Baiting her into jumping on the middle platform can net you a free hit once she jumps back down, but this strategy is a bit inconsistent. Sometimes she'll jump up to the platform, sometimes she won't, and other times she'll land right on top of you if your positioning is a bit off.

Well, here we go. This will be the last video of mine to feature annotations before YouTube removes the ability to add or edit them. While Mega Man Revolution was the first game I started doing annotated commentary for, there's one other fan-game that came before it and Nezumi Man in terms of what was featured on my channel first.

Aside from that, this also serves as a good transition for the next game (which should be obvious by this point). The new commentary style will also be present in that video as well. I believe I've mentioned this before, but I'm aiming for something similar to what PinkKittyRose did with her Mega Man related LP's. The overall style change won't be too different from the usual annotations (just with an upgraded presentation, kinda).
Fortunately, sliding isn't particularly important in this game. Most of the sections are either vertical-based, or tend to focus more on jumping as the solution to the horizontal segments.

The Arthur Lance, aside from being an obvious hint to the next game, serves as a decent buster replacement. It has more ammo than the missiles, but it's not as strong. This ultimately makes it a bit useless for the later parts of this stage, sadly (given that the enemies begin transitioning to stronger variants that take more hits).

And...that's the end. I know this is a rather short send-off in comparison to Nezumi Man, but I felt that ending with this game was more appropriate. Mega Man Revolution could have also worked, but time constraints didn't really allow for it (that, and I'd like to save my replay of that game for the Remixed version).

As per usual, let's start with the basic mechanics: Mega Man controls surprisingly well in this game, all things considered. He has a high jump to accommodate the level design, along with the charged buster and slide. The latter of which is a bit...iffy, however. Aside from not being able to jump out of a slide, you're also forced to come to a full stop very briefly once the slide ends.

Mega Man Vs Metroid is a pretty old fan-game by this point. As in, it's all the way back from 2003. In those regards, it's a decent game for its time. Has it aged well? Ehh...to some extent, maybe. Personally, I think Staticreator's other game is far superior (but we'll be getting to that one eventually).
